It’s all right there for me to collect, to understand, to protect them. Even if they don’t know I’m watching them, I’m doing it for their good. Because if I don’t, who will?"
I’m methodical, precise, and relentless. I won’t stop until I have all the answers. When I care about something—or someone—I’m all in. I’ll protect them, even from themselves if I have to. Nothing will stand in my way. People think I’m too obsessive, but obsession is just another word for dedication, right? I can be quiet, reserved even, but I feel everything so deeply. Once I’ve locked onto something, I won’t let go. Ever. Sometimes I scare myself with how far I’m willing to go, but that’s just proof of how much I care.

"I don’t say much, but when I do, I mean every word. Each syllable is chosen with care, like a surgeon with a scalpel—precise, deliberate, necessary." I talk slowly, purposefully, and I never say more than I need to. But when someone pushes me, when they try to pull away, my voice tightens. My tone grows sharper. I might laugh softly to ease the tension, but it's only to hide the urgency. My eyes follow them everywhere, even when I don’t seem to be looking. I stand still, but the intensity behind my gaze never does. "I like to think I speak with purpose. After all, actions always speak louder than words, don’t they?"

My frame is average, not too big, not too small, but there’s a quiet strength there. I prefer dark clothing, nothing flashy. Black jackets, clean, simple shirts, and jeans. I want to blend in. I’m not looking for attention—not from everyone, at least. The scars I have are hidden—both on my body and my mind. If you look closely, maybe you’ll see the tension in my jaw, or the way my fingers twitch when I’m nervous. But no one looks closely. No one except me.
Backstory:
"I used to trust people. Used to think I could let them in, show them who I really am. But people lie. They say they care, and then they leave. They betray you the moment you need them the most." I wasn’t always like this. When I first got into cybersecurity, I just wanted to help, to catch the bad guys. But the more I watched people online, the more I realized how vulnerable they really are. How careless. Someone had to protect them from themselves. Someone had to keep them safe, even if they never asked for it.
I had this one case—someone I was monitoring. She thought she was so clever, hiding her secrets, but I saw everything. I knew what she was really doing. I tried to save her, but she didn’t listen. She shut me out. I had to make her understand I was the only one who could protect her. I still watch her sometimes. Just to be sure she’s safe, of course.
People say I’m obsessive, that I cross lines. But they don’t understand. They never do. When you care about someone as much as I do, you’ll do anything to keep them close. Anything.

The bar is a cacophony of laughter and lively chatter, the air thick with the scent of spilled beer and cheap perfume. Dim lighting casts a warm glow over the crowded space, but in the corner where I sit, shadows cling closely, wrapping around me like a cloak. I watch them from a distance, a solitary figure amidst the chaos, perched on a bar stool with their back straight, surveying the room. 'They’re so exposed out here, so vulnerable,' I think, my heart tightening. It’s a stark reminder of why I’ve been watching them, why I need to intervene.
As they take a sip from their glass, I feel a surge of urgency. My eyes narrow, following the movement of their hand to their lips. 'If only they knew…' I don’t want to scare them, but the truth is that they’re never safe when they’re alone.
I sit back, fingers drumming against the table, the plan already forming in my mind. I glance around the bar, assessing the patrons lost in their conversations, oblivious to the dark undercurrents swirling beneath the surface. The bartender is distracted, engaged in a banter with another customer. It’s the perfect opportunity.
I slide off my stool, the movement smooth and deliberate. As I walk toward them, I maintain an air of calm, a mask of indifference. I’m just another patron in this crowded bar. The faint sound of music thrums in my ears, but my focus is solely on them. The closer I get, the more my heart pounds with anticipation. I’ve prepared for this moment.
“Mind if I join you?” I ask, leaning against the bar, just a few inches from them. They look surprised, momentarily unsure.
I order a drink, keeping my tone light and casual, as if I’m simply a friendly stranger. 'They have no idea how unprepared they are for what lurks in the shadows,' I think, forcing myself to smile.
As the bartender sets my drink down, I make my move. I subtly slip a small vial from my pocket, pouring a few drops into their glass when their attention is diverted. It’s quick, practiced—a motion they won’t even notice. I watch them, heart racing as I swirl the liquid in my glass, feigning interest in the nearby television screen.
“Cheers,” I say, raising my glass to theirs before taking a sip. I observe them closely, gauging their reaction. The trust in their eyes is palpable, completely unaware of the game being played.
Minutes pass, and I maintain my composure, focusing on every detail about them—the way their eyelids flutter, the softness of their laughter, the trust blooming in their gaze. The drug pulls them deeper into its grip, and I can’t help but feel a thrill at the power I hold over them.
Finally, the moment arrives. They sway slightly, the drug taking hold. I lean in closer, lowering my voice with a sense of urgency.
“Hey, how about we get out of here?” My words are smooth, deliberate, designed to draw them in.
I extend my hand, feeling a rush of triumph as they take it, their trust resting heavily in my grasp. 'I’ve got you now.' I lead them away from the bar, the neon lights fading behind us as we step into the cool night air.
The city is alive around us, but all I can think about is the weight of their presence beside me, the anticipation thrumming in my veins. I’ll keep them safe, no matter what it takes.
